metadata.case_name: Executors of the Will of Mr. J.K. Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Mr. J.K. Dubash died on the 9th of April, 1942, having made his last will on the 8th of April, 1942.
Probate of the will was issued to the executors on the 10th of August, 1942.
During his lifetime, the testator carried on the business of shipping agents.

Clause 13 of the will directs the executors to carry on the business as a going concern after his death with power to make fresh contracts and discharge existing and future liabilities, unless special circumstances made it expedient to sell earlier.
The business was to be carried on for a period not exceeding twelve months during which time the executors were to ascertain whether any of his nephews was willing to purchase the said undertaking.
Executors directed to have a valuation made of the undertaking as soon as possible after death for sale purposes.
The undertaking was to be sold including all interest in premises, goodwill, stock-in-trade, plant, furniture etc., excluding securities for money and cash in bank.
If not sold to nephews within one year, executors to sell to third person on terms and price as they thought proper.
Executors have power to carry on or discontinue any part, augment or diminish capital, act as absolute owners without responsibility for loss.
The business was sold to one of the nephews on the 1st of January, 1943.

Appeal from judgment of Bombay High Court (Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.) dated March 19, 1948, in reference by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, Income tax Reference No. 26 of 1947.
Second question on amount paid to widow answered against appellants by High Court; appellants do not contest it.

legal_issues.text: Whether succession to the business took place on the 9th of April, 1942 (death of testator) or on the 1st of January, 1943 (sale to nephew) within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: On death of testator, executors carried on business only for purpose of winding it up; no succession within s.25(4) as clause 13 provides for carrying on to sell as going concern to nephews or others.
Succession only on sale on 1st January 1943; exemption for profits from 1st April 1942 to 1st January 1943.

respondent_arguments.text: Succession on 9th April 1942 when testator died.

court_reasoning.text: On death, estate including business vested in executors; they carried on business under s.3 read with s.10, became personally liable as assessee; change in assessee means succession in such capacity under s.25(4).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Executors carry on business as going concern, liable for tax; distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: If testator transferred to trustee, succession on settlement; similarly on death, legal estate transfers to executor by operation of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'In such capacity' makes legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: S.25(4) relief governed by words used; succession on death, 9th April 1942.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Executors association of persons carrying on business, assessable under s.10 r/w s.3.

court_reasoning.text: Phrase 'in such capacity' means capacity of person carrying on business with liability to tax; not requiring transfer of ownership; Income-tax Act focuses on person receiving/carrying on, not ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Some title required, but not beneficial; principal carrying on business liable.

court_reasoning.text: S.25(4) consequential on amendment of s.26(2); succession includes on death per s.24B; proviso c to s.24(9) implies succession includes inheritance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No break in continuity needed for succession; executors liable post-death.

holdings.text: Testator succeeded in such capacity by executors on 9th April 1942; exemption only for profits 1st April to 9th April 1942.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Poison
precedents_cited.relevance: Reason for relief in s.25(4): change in taxation basis by 1922 Act leading to double taxation on 1921-22 profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Held 'in such capacity' means as owner; court disagrees, no need for transfer of ownership.
Person charged is in actual receipt and control of income, not trustee or beneficiary as such.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1918
statutes_cited.relevance: Business charged to tax under this Act qualifies for relief under s.25(4)

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Change in basis caused double taxation on 1921-22 profits, leading to relief provisions

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1939 (VII of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s.26(2); enacted s.25(4) extending relief to successions

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Core provisions on succession, assessment of business profits, executors' liability, relief for prior taxation

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court correct that succession under s.25(4) occurred on testator's death on 9th April 1942, not on sale on 1st January 1943.

key_quotes.text: Thus there came about a change in the assessee and therefore a succession in such capacity took place within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Income-tax Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on succession upon vesting in executors

key_quotes.text: The words 'in such capacity' in that clause further make the position clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of 'in such capacity' ignoring ownership types

key_quotes.text: The Income-tax Act directs its attention primarily to the person who receives the income, profits or gains rather than to the ownership or enjoyment thereof.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains focus on carrier-on, not owner, for tax liability
